description: This course provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.
name: CORPORATE FINANCE

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; security market efficiency; optimal capital structure; and dividend policy decisions. 

Students indicated that the course consisted of “a lot of valuable material” that was “quite applicable to the real world.” 

While students acknowledged Professor Kiku’s intelligence and ability to “articulate concepts clearly during lectures,” they also described her as somewhat “distant” on occasion. One student described the professor’s personality teaching style as “no-nonsense,” but that she was “more friendly during office hours.” 

The dense material, strict grading, heavily weighted exams, and rapid pace of the class made it difficult according to some, especially for a 100-level course.

This course provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; security market efficiency; optimal capital structure; and dividend policy decisions. 

Students indicated that the course consisted of “a lot of valuable material” that was “quite applicable to the real world.” 

While students acknowledged Professor Kiku’s intelligence and ability to “articulate concepts clearly during lectures,” they also described her as somewhat “distant” on occasion. One student described the professor’s personality teaching style as “no-nonsense,” but that she was “more friendly during office hours.” 

The dense material, strict grading, heavily weighted exams, and rapid pace of the class made it difficult according to some, especially for a 100-level course.

This course provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; security market efficiency; optimal capital structure; and dividend policy decisions. 

The course material was described as a great introduction to finance, with many real-world applications. However, one student commented that the material included “a lot of information for those who don’t follow finance.” Some students noted that the textbook was the most effective resource for absorbing course material. 

Students generally agreed that Professor Shaliastovich is a caring teacher who “truly wants us to succeed.” “The professor was very friendly and did a great job of maintaining student interest and communicating ideas effectively,” one student said. Another expressed an appreciation of the professor’s effort to connect with the students, as the optional weekly lunches provided students “access to his thoughts and experiences.” Furthermore, the professor was “accessible, always willing to answer questions after class, set up meetings with students or extend office hours.” 

According to one student, “The problem sets for this class were optional, but they're definitely the key to success in this course.” Another student was pleased that the course was “collegiate, not cutthroat as in other Wharton courses.”
